page.title: 03CORONATION STONE, KINGSTON
page.content: The stone stands opposite the Guildhall and is next to the Hogsmill River. Seven{Anglo-Saxon}kings were crowned at Kingston. It is about 1m by 0.79m high. It is grey with blue railings round it with posts at every metre. The stone itself is over a thousand years old. There is a sign with three fishes on it, this is the badge of Kingston. The following list shows which Kings were crowned and the year in which they were crowned:- {Edward the Elder,}son of Alfred the Great (900),{Athlestan}(925),{Edmund} (940),{Edred}(946),{Edwy}(956),{Edward {the Martyr}(975) and{Ethelred II} (979). A silver penny of the reign of each of these kings was set into the plinth of the stone, probably in 1850.
